Facebook Inc. FB, -1.58% Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg asked staff to investigate George Soros' financial interests in January after the billionaire criticized Facebook during a speech at Davos, Switzerland, the New York Times reported Thursday night.

After first denying she knew that Facebook had targeted Soros through that firm, Sandberg later walked that back, saying "it was never anyone's intention to play into an anti-Semitic narrative against Mr. Soros or anyone else."
That was before the Cambridge Analytica scandal had been revealed, but after revelations of Russian interference in the 2016 election and Facebook-fueled genocide in Myanmar.
The Times said she asked senior communication and policy executives via email to find out if Soros was attempting to financially benefit by short selling the stock.
In his speech, Soros blasted Facebook and Alphabet's Google as a "menace" to society and "obstacles to innovation."
Facebook later hired an opposition-research firm that led to anti-Semitic attacks against Soros.
